The acquisition information for the two love birds acquired by the facility on 7 Dec 2023 is incomplete. There is no name,
address, USDA license, or other identification (if not licensed under the Act) recorded for the person from whom the birds
were acquired. Complete information regarding the inventory of animals aids in the inspection process and allows for the
tracking of movement of animals regulated under the Animal Welfare Act. The licensee must make, keep, and maintain
records or forms which fully and correctly disclose all of the information required in this section of the AWA concerning
their animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or
her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. To be corrected
by 10 Jan 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility's Environmental Enhancement plan for birds does not include special considerations for individually housed
social species of birds that are unable to see and hear birds of their own or compatible species. There is one Green
Cheek Conure currently housed by itself in the clinic area for prescribed medical treatment. This bird is unable to see or
hear compatible birds. Failure to develop and follow a plan for birds requiring special consideration may result in
inadequate care in promoting and addressing their psychological well-being. Certain birds must be provided special
attention regarding enhancement of their environment in accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian. To
be corrected by 10 Jan 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There are excessive mounds of accumulated excreta on one of the perches and on the bottoms of the enclosures housing
the Amazon Parrot, the Blue and Gold Macaw, the Military Macaw, and the Moluccan Cockatoo. Insufficient cleaning and
sanitization of primary enclosures for birds can result in poor air quality in the area, attract pests, cause odors and play a
role in disease transmission. The licensee must ensure that excreta and food waste must be removed from primary
enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of
feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the birds contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards,
insects, pests, and odors. To be corrected by 5 Jan 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
